_**Batman**_ (often promoted as _**Batman: The Movie**_) is a 1966 American
[superhero film](/wiki/Superhero_film "Superhero film") based on the [_Batman_
television series](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman \(TV series\)"), and the
first full-length theatrical adaptation of the [DC Comics](/wiki/DC_Comics "DC
Comics") character [Batman](/wiki/Batman "Batman"). Released by [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox"), the film starred [Adam
West](/wiki/Adam_West "Adam West") as Batman and [Burt Ward](/wiki/Burt_Ward
"Burt Ward") as [Robin](/wiki/Robin_\(comics\) "Robin \(comics\)"). The film
hit theaters two months after the [last episode of the first
season](/wiki/List_of_Batman_television_episodes#Season_1:_1966 "List of
Batman television episodes") of the television series. The film includes most
members of the original TV cast, with the exception of [Lee
Meriwether](/wiki/Lee_Meriwether "Lee Meriwether") as the Catwoman, the
character previously played by [Julie Newmar](/wiki/Julie_Newmar "Julie
Newmar") in two episodes of the series' first season.

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

When Batman and Robin get a tip that Commodore Schmidlapp is in danger aboard
his yacht, they launch a rescue mission using the [Batcopter](/wiki/Batcopter
"Batcopter"). As Batman descends on the bat-ladder to land on the yacht, it
suddenly vanishes beneath him. He rises out of the sea with a shark attacking
his leg. After Batman dislodges it with bat-[shark
repellent](/wiki/Shark_repellent "Shark repellent"), the shark explodes.
Batman and Robin head back to Commissioner Gordon's office, where they deduce
that the tip was a set-up by the United Underworld, a gathering of four of the
most powerful villains in [Gotham City](/wiki/Gotham_City "Gotham City") ([The
Joker](/wiki/Joker_\(character\) "Joker \(character\)"), [The
Penguin](/wiki/Penguin_\(character\) "Penguin \(character\)"), [The
Riddler](/wiki/Riddler "Riddler"), and [The Catwoman](/wiki/Catwoman
"Catwoman")).

The United Underworld equip themselves with a dehydrator that can turn humans
into dust (an invention of Schmidlapp, who is unaware that he has been
kidnapped), a submarine made to resemble a [penguin](/wiki/Penguin "Penguin"),
and their three pirate henchmen (Bluebeard, Morgan and Quetch). It is revealed
the yacht was really a projection. When Batman and Robin return to a buoy
concealing a projector, they are trapped on the buoy by a magnet and targeted
by torpedoes. They use a radio-detonator to destroy two of the missiles, and a
porpoise sacrifices itself to intercept the last one. The Catwoman, disguised
as [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") journalist "Miss Kitka", helps
the group kidnap Bruce Wayne and pretends to be kidnapped with him, as part of
a plot to lure Batman and finish him off with another of the Penguin's
explosive animals (not knowing that Bruce Wayne is Batman's alter-ego). After
Bruce Wayne escapes captivity, the Penguin disguises himself as the Commodore
and schemes his way into the [Batcave](/wiki/Batcave "Batcave") along with
five dehydrated henchmen. This plan fails when the henchmen unexpectedly
disappear into [antimatter](/wiki/Antimatter "Antimatter") once struck: The
Penguin mistakenly rehydrated them with [heavy water](/wiki/Heavy_water "Heavy
water"), used to recharge the Batcave's [atomic pile](/wiki/Atomic_pile
"Atomic pile").

Ultimately, Batman and Robin are unable to prevent the kidnapping of the
dehydrated [United World Organization's Security
Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security
Council"). Giving chase in the [batboat](/wiki/Batboat "Batboat") to retrieve
them (and Miss Kitka, presumed by the duo as still captive), Robin uses a
sonic charge weapon to disable Penguin's submarine and force it to surface,
where a fist fight ensues. Although Batman and Robin win the fight, Batman is
heartbroken to find out that his "true love" Miss Kitka is actually the
Catwoman when her mask falls off. Commodore Schmidlapp accidentally breaks the
vials containing the powdered Council members, mixing them together.

Batman sets to work, constructing an elaborate filter to separate the mingled
dust. Robin asks him whether it might be in the world's best interests for
them to alter the dust samples, so that humans can no longer harm one another.
In response, Batman says that they cannot do so, reminding Robin of the fate
of the Penguin's henchmen and their tainted rehydration, and can only hope for
people in general to learn to live together peacefully on their own.

With the world watching, the [Security Council](/wiki/Security_Council
"Security Council") is re-hydrated. All of the members are restored alive and
well, continuing to squabble among themselves and totally oblivious of their
surroundings, but each of them now speaks the language and displays the
stereotypical mannerisms of a nation other than their own. Batman quietly
expresses his sincere hope to Robin that this "mixing of minds" does more good
than it does harm. The duo quietly leave [United World
Headquarters](/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters "United Nations Headquarters")
by climbing out of the window and descending on their batropes.

The film includes most members of the original TV cast: the actors for Batman,
Robin, Alfred, Gordon, O'Hara, Aunt Harriet, the Joker, the Penguin, and the
Riddler all reprised their roles. Though [Julie Newmar](/wiki/Julie_Newmar
"Julie Newmar") had at this point played [Catwoman](/wiki/Catwoman "Catwoman")
in two episodes of [season
one](/wiki/List_of_Batman_television_episodes#Season_1:_1966 "List of Batman
television episodes") in the [TV series](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman
\(TV series\)"), she had other commitments at that time[5] and was replaced by
[Lee Meriwether](/wiki/Lee_Meriwether "Lee Meriwether") in the film. According
to the [Biography](/wiki/Biography_\(TV_Series\) "Biography \(TV Series\)")
special [Catwoman](/wiki/Catwoman "Catwoman"): Her Many Lives, aired on July
20, 2004, it was stated that Newmar was unable to reprise her role due to a
reported back injury. [Catwoman](/wiki/Catwoman "Catwoman") was nonetheless
played by Newmar once again in the following eleven episodes of [season
two](/wiki/List_of_Batman_television_episodes#Season_2:_1966–67 "List of
Batman television episodes") of the series; [Eartha Kitt](/wiki/Eartha_Kitt
"Eartha Kitt") would then play [Catwoman](/wiki/Catwoman "Catwoman") in three
episodes of [season
three](/wiki/List_of_Batman_television_episodes#Season_3:_1967–68 "List of
Batman television episodes").

In his autobiography, [Adam West](/wiki/Adam_West "Adam West") writes of his
asking for more money to do the film and that the producers countered with the
fact that another actor would be hired. _Batman_ was Denny's final film
appearance. [Jack LaLanne](/wiki/Jack_LaLanne "Jack LaLanne") has a cameo as a
man on a rooftop with bikini-clad women.[6]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

[William Dozier](/wiki/William_Dozier "William Dozier") wanted to make a big-
screen film to generate interest in his proposed [Batman](/wiki/Batman
"Batman") TV series by having the feature in theaters while the first season
of the series was rolling before the cameras. The studio, [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox"), refused because it would have
to cover the entire cost of a movie, while it would only have to share the
cost of a TV series (a much less risky proposition).[7]

The film features many characters from the show. It was written by series
writer [Lorenzo Semple, Jr.](/wiki/Lorenzo_Semple,_Jr. "Lorenzo Semple, Jr.")
and directed by [Leslie H. Martinson](/wiki/Leslie_H._Martinson "Leslie H.
Martinson").[8] Martinson had directed a pair of the television series season
one episodes: "The Penguin Goes Straight" and "Not Yet, He Ain't".

### Tone[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Tone")]

Even though it is often described (like many contemporary shows) as a parody
of a popular comic-book character, some commentators believe that its comedy
is not so tightly confined. They felt the film's depiction of the Caped
Crusader "captured the feel of the contemporary comics perfectly".[9] The film
was, they remind us, made at a time when "the Batman of the [Golden Age
comics](/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Comic_Books "Golden Age of Comic Books") was
already essentially neutered."[10]

Certain elements verge into direct parody of the history of Batman. The movie,
like the TV series, is strongly influenced by the comparatively obscure 1940s
serials of Batman, such as the escapes done almost out of luck.[10] The
penchant for giving devices a "Bat-" prefix and the dramatic use of stylized
title cards during fight scenes acknowledge some of the conventions that the
character had accumulated in various media. However, the majority of _Batman_
's campier moments can be read as a broader parody on contemporary mid-1960s
culture in general.[11]

Furthermore, the movie represented Batman's first major foray into [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") issues paying heavy attention to [Polaris
Missiles](/wiki/UGM-27_Polaris "UGM-27 Polaris"), [war surplus
submarines](/wiki/War_surplus "War surplus") and taking a poke at [the
Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon"). The inclusion of a glory-hunting
presidential character and the unfavorable portrayal of Security Council
Members marked Batman's first attempts to poke fun at domestic and
international politics.[12]

###
Vehicles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Vehicles")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/1960s_Batmobile_%28FMC%29.jpg/220px-1960s_Batmobile_%28FMC%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:1960s_Batmobile_\(FMC\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1960s_Batmobile_\(FMC\).jpg "Enlarge")

The Batmobile as seen in the 1960s _Batman_ TV series.

Besides the [Batmobile](/wiki/Batmobile "Batmobile"), other vehicles used by
The Dynamic Duo include:

  * [Batcycle](/wiki/Batcycle "Batcycle") with side car
  * [Batboat](/wiki/Batboat "Batboat"), provided by [Glastron](/wiki/Glastron "Glastron")
  * [Batcopter](/wiki/Batcopter "Batcopter")

Of the three new Batvehicles which first appeared in the _Batman_ film, only
the [Batcycle](/wiki/Batcycle "Batcycle") properly crossed over into the [TV
series](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman \(TV series\)") as the budgetary
limits of the TV series precluded the full use of the others. While the
[Batcopter](/wiki/Batcopter "Batcopter") and [Batboat](/wiki/Batboat
"Batboat") from the movie appeared briefly in episodes (including a use of the
Batboat in the conclusion of the first post-film two-parter: "[Walk the
Straight and Narrow](/wiki/Walk_the_Straight_and_Narrow "Walk the Straight and
Narrow")"), they primarily did so in the form of stock-footage scenes from the
film intercut into the series.

##
Soundtrack[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Soundtrack")]

[Nelson Riddle](/wiki/Nelson_Riddle "Nelson Riddle")'s original score to
_Batman the Movie_ was released in 2010 by [La-La Land Records](/wiki/La-
La_Land_Records "La-La Land Records") and [Fox Music](/wiki/Fox_Music "Fox
Music"). The album contains the entire score as heard in the film in
chronological order as well as an unreleased cue. This limited edition
includes a lavishly illustrated color booklet which features exclusive liner
notes by Brian Baterwhite. This Limited Edition was of 2000 units.

It was newly re-issued in 2016. While the program and master of this release
is identical to the 2010 release, this reissue features all-new exclusive
liner notes by John Takis and art design by Jim Titus. This new Limited
Edition is of 2500 units.

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Release")]

_Batman_ premiered at the [Paramount
Theatre](/wiki/Paramount_Theatre_\(Austin,_Texas\) "Paramount Theatre
\(Austin, Texas\)") in [Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas") on
July 30, 1966 (between the first and second seasons of the [TV
series](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman \(TV series\)")); it was moderately
successful at the box office. The [Batboat](/wiki/Batboat "Batboat") featured
in the film was created by Austin-based company [Glastron](/wiki/Glastron
"Glastron"), whose payment was in having the film premiere in their hometown.
In conjunction with the premiere, Jean Boone of Austin CBS affiliate station
[KTBC](/wiki/KTBC_\(TV\) "KTBC \(TV\)") interviewed the film's cast, including
[Lee Meriwether](/wiki/Lee_Meriwether "Lee Meriwether"), [Cesar
Romero](/wiki/Cesar_Romero "Cesar Romero"), and [Adam West](/wiki/Adam_West
"Adam West").[13]

ABC, the network which previously aired the [_Batman_ television
series](/wiki/Batman_\(TV_series\) "Batman \(TV series\)"), first broadcast
the film on the July 4, 1971 edition of _[The ABC Sunday Night
Movie](/wiki/The_ABC_Sunday_Night_Movie "The ABC Sunday Night Movie")_ ; the
film was quickly rebroadcast on ABC September 4 of that year. The film debuted
on home video via formats [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") and [Betamax](/wiki/Betamax
"Betamax") release in 1985 by [Playhouse Video](/wiki/CBS/Fox_Video "CBS/Fox
Video"), in 1989 by [CBS/Fox Video](/wiki/CBS/Fox_Video "CBS/Fox Video"), and
in 1994 by [Fox Video](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox_Home_Entertainment "20th Century
Fox Home Entertainment"). The film was released on DVD in 2001, and re-
released July 1, 2008 on [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") and on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-
ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc").[14]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Batman_\(1966_film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Reception")]

The film has received generally positive reviews over the years. On [review
aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the film has an 80% rating
based on 30 reviews, with an average rating of 6.2/10. The site's consensus
states: "_Batman: The Movie_ elevates [camp](/wiki/Camp_\(style\) "Camp
\(style\)") to an art form -- and has a blast doing it, every gloriously
tongue-in-cheek inch of the way."[15] Bill Gibron of Filmcritic.com gave the
film 3 out of 5 stars: "Unlike other attempts at bringing these characters to
life...the TV cast really captures the inherent insanity of the roles."[16]
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ magazine stated
on their review that "the intense innocent enthusiasm of Cesar Romero, Burgess
Meredith and Frank Gorshin as the three criminals is balanced against the
innocent calm of Adam West and Burt Ward, Batman and Robin respectively."[17]
